awd_titl_txt: Understanding the evolutionary transition between annual and perennial life history strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will address one of the most fundamental questions faced by all organisms: when is the best time to reproduce to maximize the survival and success of their offspring. In plants, there are two broad categories of reproductive strategies; annuals that reproduce once and die, and perennials that reproduce repeatedly and cycle through vegetative and reproductive phases. This research will utilize a model plant system, Mimulus guttatus, commonly known as Monkeyflower, native to the west coast of the United States to investigate the ecological and genetic mechanisms underlying flowering time differences in annuals and perennial plant species. The focus on the role of environmental cues, including daylength and temperature, in the transition to flowering is particularly pertinent. This is because climate change is altering temperature patterns and moisture levels that are going to challenge many plant species ability to persist under these new environmental regimes.

This project will benefit the scientific community by the development of genomic resources that will enhance our general understanding of what forces influence transitions between reproducing once and dying versus reproducing multiple times prior to senescence. The integrative nature of this proposed research means that students and postdoctoral fellows will receive cross-disciplinary training, and the research also provides training opportunities for high school and undergraduate students. Additionally the public will benefit through collaborations with the popular Milton J. Rubenstein Museum of Science & Technology by providing mentoring to the staff and public workshops to serve the city of Syracuse's middle and high school students.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental question relevant to all organisms is when is the best time to reproduce? There is remarkable variation in the timing of growth, reproduction and death, and it’s not clear why this variation exists. We used the model plant species Mimulus guttatus to understand the selective forces and genetic mechanisms that are responsible for the origins and maintenance of reproductive diversity. We specifically focussed on differences between annuals and perennials, as this is one of the major life history differences in plants. Within the species M. guttatus, there are populations that are annual where individuals flower rapidly and die shortly thereafter; and populations that are perennial where plants make clonal runners, flower later in the season, and persist for multiple years. We leveraged this natural variation within a single species to understand the maintenance and selection on life history strategies.

Through a series of experiments in greenhouses, growth chambers and the field, we found that plants use differences in daylength to time their flowering, and have specific genetic mechanisms to sense cold. This means that individuals can time their germination and flowering to natural temperature fluctuations and to their local environment. We also found that there are trade-offs between flowering and clonal growth, and the optimal strategy depends on environmental conditions. In a large field experiment where we recombined genes between annuals and perennials, we were surprised to find that individuals could indeed invest in both high clonal growth and many flowers. This suggest that there may not be strong genetic constraints on allocation strategies, and existing variation may represent adaptive differences between populations. Populations contain ample genetic variation for these traits, so it’s possible that future environmental changes may select for different strategies.

The project also benefited the scientific community and the public by including outreach and training components. The integrative nature of the research allowed students and postdoctoral fellows to receive cross-disciplinary training with extensive fieldwork, data analysis and molecular genomics. The project provided opportunities for high school and undergraduate students to participate in research. Finally, we began a collaboration with the Westcott Community After-School Program and the Syracuse City School District. We led monthly activities for school-aged children, where children were actively engaged in scientific discovery and learned hands-on skills through inquiry-based learning.
